Fixed-term contract for a period of more than 1 school year

Year(s) working as a teacher in total

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: <ISCED 2>
<ISCED 3>

text.strong: ‌During your most recent complete calendar week, approximately how many 60-minute hours did you spend in total on tasks related to your job at this school?‌

text.em: ‌Include time spent on teaching, planning lessons, <marking>, collaborating with other teachers, participating in staff meetings, participating in professional development and other work tasks. Also include tasks that took place during evenings, the weekend or other out of class hours.‌
‌A ‘complete’ calendar week is one that was not shortened by breaks, public holidays, sick leave, etc.‌
‌(Please type a number. Please round to the nearest whole hour.)‌

label.text: Hours

text.strong: ‌How many 60-minute hours did you spend on the following tasks during your most recent complete calendar week at this school?‌

text.em: ‌Include tasks that took place during class hours, weekends, and evenings.‌
‌(Please type a number. Please round to the nearest whole hour. If you did not perform the task during the most recent complete calendar week, type "0" (zero).)‌

label.text: Teaching
Individual planning or preparation of lessons either at school or out of school
Teamwork and dialogue with colleagues within this school
Marking/correcting of student work
Counselling students (including student supervision, mentoring, virtual counselling, career guidance and behaviour guidance)
General administrative work (including communication, paperwork and other clerical duties)
Communication and co-operation with parents or guardians
Engaging in extracurricular activities (e.g. sports and cultural activities after school)

text.strong: ‌Across all of the classes you are teaching, what proportion of your students are students with <special needs>?‌

text.em: ‌‘Students with <special needs>’ are those for whom a special learning need has been formally identified because they are mentally, physically, or emotionally disadvantaged. [Often they will be those for whom additional public or private resources (personnel, material or financial) have been provided to support their education.]‌

label.text: None
Some
Most
All

No

text.strong: ‌What proportion of your science teacher education or training programme or other professional qualification was dedicated to each of the following areas?‌

text.em: ‌(For each area please enter an approximate percentage, e.g. “20” in the first row to indicate 20 % of initial education time used for science.)‌
‌(Note that the percentages must add up to 100.)‌

label.text: Science: knowledge and skills related to science domain
Pedagogy of science: knowledge and methodology of science instructional skills (evidence-based strategies, model-based approach, guided discussion, inquiry)
Practical science instruction: laboratory safety and experimental design
General pedagogical knowledge: e.g. teacher-student interaction, classroom management, school evaluation, special education

text.strong: ‌During the last 12 months, did you participate in any of the following activities?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Qualification programme (e.g. a <degree programme>)
Participation in a network of teachers formed specifically for the professional development of teachers
Individual or collaborative research on a topic of interest to you professionally
Mentoring and/or peer observation and coaching, as part of a formal school arrangement
Reading professional literature (e.g. journals, evidence-based papers, thesis papers)
Engaging in informal dialogue with your colleagues on how to improve your teaching
Course, workshop, or conference on teaching methods
Course, workshop, or conference relevant to your subject-matter field
Observation visits to other schools
Training courses in private companies or other organisations
Listening to or watching recorded seminars or online courses (e.g. <MOOCs>) about the use of <digital resources> for teaching
Course, workshop, or conference about the use of <digital resources> for teaching
In-service training courses about the use of <digital resources> for teaching
Learning new pedagogical or instructional approaches with <digital resources>

text.strong: ‌During the last 12 months, what proportion of your science professional development activities was dedicated to each of the following areas?‌

text.em: ‌(For each area please enter an approximate percentage, e.g. “20” in the first row to indicate 20 % of professional development activity time used for science.)‌

label.text: Science: knowledge and skills related to science domain
Pedagogy of science: knowledge and methodology of science instructional skills (evidence-based strategies, model-based approach, guided discussion, inquiry)
Practical Science instruction: laboratory safety and experimental design

text.strong: ‌Are you required to take part in professional development activities?‌

label.text: Yes
No

text.strong: ‌How is <school science> instruction organized at your school?‌

label.text: It is divided into separate subject classes (e.g. biology, physics, and chemistry)
It is combined/integrated in a “general” science class

text.strong: ‌Are <school science> classes compulsory for students?‌

label.text: Yes
No

text.strong: ‌Are <school science> classes taught for the entire school year?‌

label.text: Yes
No

text.strong: ‌Do science teachers teach one or more than one subject area of school science?‌

label.text: One subject area of school science
More than one subject area of school science

text.strong: ‌How are students grouped in your <school science> classes?‌

label.text: By ability within their <school science> classes
By ability in different <school science> classes
They are not grouped at all

text.strong: ‌How much emphasis is given to the following approaches and processes in the intended <school science> curriculum for <the national modal grade of 15-year-olds>?‌

label.text: Knowing basic science facts and principles
Observing natural phenomena and describing what is seen
Providing explanations of what is being studied
Designing and planning experiments or investigations
Conducting experiments or investigations
Integrating science with other subjects
Relating what students are learning to their daily lives
Incorporating the experiences of different ethnic/cultural groups
Integrating <education for sustainability> and/or <environmental science> within topics
Teaching scientific practices related to making an argument based on evidence
Teaching scientific practices by developing and using explanatory models
Interrogating sources of information
Using evidence to support scientific arguments

text.strong: ‌Have you taught the following areas of <school science> to students in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds> in the past two school years?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌
‌Yes, for one week of lessons or less‌
‌Yes, for more than one week of lessons‌

label.text: Structure of the Earth (e.g. plate tectonics, layers of the Earth, rock cycle)
Atmosphere, weather and climate
Force and motion
Electricity
Chemical reactions
Structure and function of the human body
Sexual and asexual reproduction
Evolution
Climate change
Environments and habitats
Ecosystems (e.g. food web, habitat)
Interactions between global systems
The processes and practices of scientific enquiry
Atomic structure
Properties of matter
Our solar system and its place in the universe
Cells and their functions
Genetics
Scientific inventions and/or discoveries and their benefits for society
Ethics of scientific experiments or investigations
Energy transfers and transformation
Disturbances to the environment (e.g. pollution, overfishing, deforestation)
Agricultural practices

text.strong: ‌How often do these things happen in your science lessons?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Many students don’t listen to what I say.
There is noise and disorder.
I have to wait a long time for students to quiet down.
Students cannot work well.
Students don’t start working for a long time after the lesson begins.
Students get distracted by using <digital resources> (e.g. smartphones, web sites, apps).
Students get distracted by other students who were using <digital resources> (e.g. smartphones, web sites, apps).
Students use scientific equipment inappropriately.
A student’s misbehaviour prevents the student from doing practical work

text.strong: ‌How often do you collaborate with your fellow <school science> teachers in the following ways?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: We discuss the achievement requirements for <school science> when setting tests.
It is natural for us to co-operate on what homework to give to our students.
We discuss the criteria we use to grade written tests.
We exchange tasks for lessons and homework that cover a range of different levels of difficulty.
I prepare a selection of teaching units with my fellow <school science> teachers.
We discuss ways to teach learning strategies and techniques to our students.
I help my fellow <school science> teachers develop skills and knowledge
We discuss ways to better identify students’ individual strengths and weaknesses.
We observe each other’s classes to improve the quality of our teaching
We demonstrate the use of scientific equipment to each other
We demonstrate how to do experiments to each other
We discuss how to teach environmental issues
We discuss the teaching of scientific practices

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you agree with the following statements about leadership in your school?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: My <leadership team> always explains their decisions.
The <leadership team> always puts teaching and learning at the forefront of their decisions.
I feel supported in my teaching and learning by my <leadership team>.
My <leadership team> has defined their shared expectations of staff and students.
My <leadership team> uses resources strategically to build teaching and learning capabilities.
My <leadership team> promotes a positive school learning environment.
My <leadership team> both participates and encourages teachers to develop their leadership skills and knowledge.
<National addition 306>

text.strong: ‌Is your school’s capacity to provide instruction hindered by any of the following issues?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: A lack of teaching staff
Poorly qualified teaching staff
A lack of assisting staff (e.g. teacher aides, laboratory technicians, administration staff)
Poorly qualified assisting staff (e.g. teacher aides, laboratory technicians, administration staff)
A lack of educational material (e.g. textbooks, IT equipment, library or laboratory material)
Inadequate laboratory space
Inadequate or poor-quality educational material (e.g. textbooks, IT equipment, library or laboratory material)
A lack of physical infrastructure (e.g. building, grounds, heating/cooling, lighting and acoustic systems)
Inadequate or poor-quality physical infrastructure (e.g. building, grounds, heating/cooling, lighting and acoustic systems)

text.strong: ‌How often do you undertake the following activities with your <school science> students to improve their understanding of science?‌

label.text: Take students on an excursion to visit museums that include science related displays (e.g. natural history, space)
Take students to visit a place with a waterway (e.g. beach, river)
Organise visits with scientists to work with students
Work with students to grow a school garden
Take students to visit zoos, aquariums, or other wildlife centres
Run a science club outside of set class times
Discuss new scientific discoveries or inventions that are unrelated to the topics currently being taught
Discuss how scientific data can be misrepresented in the media and social media
Discuss pseudoscience and scientific misconceptions
Organise activities at school to positively impact the environment

text.strong: ‌How often do these things happen in your <school science> lessons?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Students are asked to draw conclusions from an experiment they have conducted.
Students are given opportunities to explain their ideas.
I explain scientific ideas.
A small group discussion between students takes place.
A whole class discussion takes place in which I participate.
Current scientific issues are discussed.
Students make calculations using scientific formulas.
I use an interactive whiteboard.
Students do their own scientific study and related research.
I discuss questions that students ask.
Students carry out practical work.
Students write up laboratory reports.
I demonstrate an idea.
I discuss questions of practical relevance.
Students read materials from a textbook.
Students take notes from the board.
Students discuss materials from a textbook.
Students watch videos.
Students use the Internet.
The class corrects homework or a test.
Students fill out worksheets.
Students present something to the rest of the class.
Students use <data loggers, data recorders> or similar technology as part of their experiments.
I use <data loggers, data recorders> or similar technology to demonstrate concepts to students.
Students use robotic technology in class.

text.strong: ‌To what extent can (or could) you do the following?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Design experiments and hands-on activities for <inquiry-based learning>
Assign tailored tasks to the weakest as well as to the best students
Use a variety of assessment strategies
Facilitate a discussion among students on how to interpret experimental findings

text.strong: ‌To what extent can (or could) you do the following?‌

text.em: ‌Your ‘scientific discipline’ refers to one specific <broad science> discipline your main <school science> subject belongs to. If you teach the same number of hours for several <school science> subjects, you should choose only one and relate your answer to it.‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Explain a complex scientific concept to a fellow teacher
State and defend an informed position on ethical problems relating to <broad science>
Read state-of-the art papers in my scientific discipline
Read recent papers on educational research on the teaching of science
Explain the links between biology, physics and chemistry
Explain the causes of climate change
Explain the effects of climate change

text.strong: ‌How much have you learnt about co-operation between parents or guardians and teachers during the following activities?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: During teacher training as a specific topic
During teacher training when it was integrated within teaching topics
During professional development workshops
During my daily teaching practice
During discussions with more experienced teaching colleagues

text.strong: ‌How often are parents or guardians involved in the following situations?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Providing general assistance to the class during day-to-day science lessons
Providing general assistance to the class during science-based excursions and when science experts visit the school
Discussing their child’s science academic performance with you
Discussing their child’s behaviour in science with you
Discussing how they can support their child’s future career in science with you
Discussing how to help their child with their science work at home with you
Discussing concerns with science curriculum content
Attending formal parent or guardian teacher interviews
Corresponding via email with you

text.strong: ‌How often do you use the following methods of <formative> assessment to evaluate student learning in <school science> classes?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I have individual students answer questions in front of the class.
I provide written feedback on student work in addition to a <mark, i.e. numeric score or letter grade>.
I let students judge their own progress.
I observe students when working on particular tasks and provide immediate feedback.
I collect data from classroom assignments or homework.
I let students assess each other’s work.
I carry out assessments at the beginning of a topic to evaluate prior learning.
I give students short written assessments whilst teaching a topic.
I ask my students to write reflections about their learning at the end of each lesson.
I use evaluations of student work provided by digital learning platforms.

text.strong: ‌How often do you use the following methods of <summative> assessments to evaluate student learning in <science> classes?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I develop and administer my own assessment at the end of topics.
I administer a <standardised test>.
I develop and administer <inquiry-based> assessments.
I develop and administer research-based projects.
I prepare experiments with guided questions so that students can write experimental reports
I assess students’ laboratory skills.
I assess students’ ability with scientific practices (e.g. evaluating evidence, developing models).

text.strong: ‌How often do you do the following whilst you are teaching <school science>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Tell students that making mistakes is part of the learning process
Encourage students to take on new challenges
Praise students who put in the effort to reach a goal
Ask students to develop learning goals for science
Instil a sense of confidence in all students
Allow students to skip a task if you feel they do not have the ability to undertake it
Build the confidence of all students in the class regardless of abilities
Ensure that students who are given differentiated tasks understand that they are working towards the same goals as other students
Give feedback on student’s strengths in science
Tell students in which areas they can still improve
Provide feedback on how students can improve their performance
Listen to students’ views on how to do things
Encourage students to ask for help in solving challenging problems
Ensure students feel like they belong in my science class

text.strong: ‌How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements about the students in your science classes?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: My students cannot improve their results as they have a certain amount of intelligence and I cannot change it.
My students can improve their results if they are given enough support based on their abilities.
My students can all reach their goals with the right amount of support.
My students are responsible for their own learning.
My students can all succeed.
My students are only successful if they get everything correct.
My students feel comfortable taking risks.
My students are very supportive of each other.
My students know that they can discuss their personal problems with me.

text.strong: ‌How much do you agree with the statements about yourself?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I enjoy learning <broad science> topics.
I enjoy teaching <broad science> topics.
I like reading about <broad science>.
I am happy working on <broad science> topics.
I enjoy acquiring new knowledge in <broad science>.
I am interested in learning about recent scientific discoveries.

text.strong: ‌How much do you agree with the following statements?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: A good way to know if something is true is to do an experiment.
Good answers are based on evidence from many different experiments.
It is good to try experiments more than once to make sure of your findings.
One important part of <broad science> is doing experiments to come up with ideas about how things work.
It is good to have a hypothesis or question before starting an experiment.
<Broad science> uses models to help develop theories about the world
Some ideas in <broad science> today are different than what scientists used to think.
Ideas in <broad science> sometimes change.
The ideas in <broad science> science books sometimes change.
Information from one source should be checked from a range of other reliable sources before it is accepted.
In <broad science>, there can be more than one way for scientists to test their ideas.
There are some questions that scientists cannot answer.
New discoveries can change what scientists think is true.
Sometimes <broad science> scientists change their minds about what is true in science.
It is important for scientists to have other scientists in their field of expertise to support the findings of their work.
The benefits of science and research are greater than potential damage.
We should rely more on common sense and less on scientific studies.

text.strong: ‌The statements below are about the advantages of using <digital resources> in teaching science. How strongly do you agree or disagree with these statements?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: <Digital resources> increase student engagement.
<Digital resources> let students access more sources of information.
<Digital resources> promote collaboration among students.
<Digital resources> improve communication with the students.
<Digital resources> are useful to monitor students’ learning and reasoning processes.
<Digital resources> help better assess students’ skills.
<Digital resources> let students do work that is similar to that of professional scientists.
<Digital resources> strengthen students’ capacity to conduct experiments.
<Digital resources> help students grasp complex concepts through multimedia presentations (e.g. simulations, virtual reality).

text.strong: ‌This school year, how often did you do the following activities?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Use <digital resources> to design tasks
Use <digital resources> to explore new teaching methods
Use <digital resources> to enable student collaboration
Use <digital resources> to provide feedback to students
Use <digital resources> to provide access to instructional material for students who cannot physically attend class
Use <digital resources> to communicate with parents or guardians
Use online tools or computer-based testing to assess students’ learning
Use <digital resources> to share ideas or resources with colleagues
Take part in professional communities of practice online
Use <digital resources> that automatically evaluate the quality of student work
Use digital learning games (e.g. <Atlantis Remixed>, <Duolingo®>) as teaching materials
Use Artificial Intelligence chatbots (e.g. <ChatGPT>, <Google Bard>) to prepare lessons

text.strong: ‌This school year, how much emphasis have you placed on teaching the following competencies to your students?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Evaluating the credibility of digital information
Sharing digital information with others (e.g. through presentations, documents, images or diagrams)
Using <digital resources> to solve real-world problems (e.g. measuring the height of a building, finding directions on a map)
Using digital tools to work collaboratively
Understanding the consequences of public dissemination of information online (privacy and safety)
Designing some kind of digital product (e.g. a game, an animation, a model)
Solving problems using computational thinking (e.g. using logical sequences of steps)

text.strong: ‌To what extent are you able to do the following tasks by using <digital resources>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌
‌I struggle to do this on my own‌
‌I can do this with a bit of effort‌

label.text: Search for and find relevant information online
Assess the quality of information you find online
Write or edit text for a formal document such as a CV (e.g. using <Google® Docs™>, <Microsoft® Word>)
Create a multi-media presentation (with sound, pictures, or video)
Create or edit videos (e.g. <iMovie, Final Cut Pro, InShot>)
Produce or edit music (e.g. <Audacity, GarageBand>)
Create a computer program (e.g. in <Scratch>, <Python>, <Java>)
Collect and record data (e.g. using data loggers, <Google® Form>, <Microsoft® Excel>
Build or edit a webpage (e.g. using <WordPress>)
Create shared documents for collaboration with others (e.g. using <Google® Docs™, Dropbox>)
Use drawing or graphic software and applications
Explain how your personal data are being collected and shared by any particular app or web site
Assess the quality of information generated by Artificial Intelligence chatbots (e.g. <ChatGPT>, <Google Bard>)

text.strong: ‌How often do you instruct your students to do the following tasks in your Science lessons or when completing homework?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Use <digital resources> to make students observe a natural system or phenomenon
Use <digital resources> to make students understand scientific concepts
Use <digital resources> to make students conduct research about a scientific topic
Use <digital resources> to collect, record, and analyse data
Use <digital resources> for simulations and modelling (e.g. <GeoGebra>, <NetLogo>),
Use virtual laboratories (e.g. <Labster>, <Phet>)
Use <digital resources> for coding or algorithm activities (e.g. <Scratch>, etc.)

text.strong: ‌How often do these situations occur in your lessons?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I explain the learning goals for the lesson or study unit to students.
I check what students already know before teaching a new topic.
I talk through my thinking when carrying out tasks with students (e.g. analysing a text, designing an experiment).
I give students advice on effective learning techniques.
I ask students to identify what resources they will need to complete a task before they get started.
I provide materials (e.g. prompts, rubrics, checklists) for students to monitor their learning progress.
I give students advice on how to manage negative emotions related to learning (e.g. frustration, anxiety, boredom).
I ask students to teach a topic to one another.
I ask students to evaluate their own work.
I ask students to evaluate the work of classmates.
I ask students to carry out challenging tasks on their own that take more than a day to complete.

text.strong: ‌In your teaching, to what extent can you do the following?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Get students to believe they can do well in schoolwork
Help my students value learning
Craft good questions for my students
Control disruptive behaviour in the classroom
Motivate students who show low interest in schoolwork
Make my expectations about student behaviour clear
Help students think critically
Teach students how to learn more effectively on their own
Teach students how to learn more effectively with <digital resources>
Get students to follow classroom rules
Calm a student who is disruptive or noisy
Use a variety of assessment strategies
Provide an alternative explanation for example when students are confused
Implement alternative instructional strategies in my classroom
Explain how to use Artificial Intelligence chatbots (e.g. <ChatGPT>, <Google Bard>)

text.strong: ‌In your lessons, have you ever taught any of the following things?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: How to use keywords when using a search engine such as <Google©>, <Yahoo©>, etc.
How to decide whether to trust information found online
How to compare different web pages and decide what information is more relevant for the students’ school work
To understand the consequences of making information publicly available online on <Facebook®>, <Instagram©>, etc.
How to use the short description below the links in the list of results of a search
How to detect whether the information is subjective or biased
How to detect phishing or spam emails
How to write computer programs
How to build a scientific model on a computer
How to create shared documents for collaboration with others (e.g. using <Google® Docs™, Dropbox>)
How students’ personal data is being collected and shared by any particular app or website
How to collect and record data (e.g. using data loggers, <Microsoft® Access™>, <Google® Form>, <Excel®>)
